>>28173680
You can always find your path, same with getting a gf. However, like other anons said by age 50 your life is mostly laid out. People who wanted kids already raised them, those that wanted to get married already did, etc. Reaching this age without some sort of life satisfaction is extremely hard without stupidly bad luck or dumb life choices, and many people fail in one of their many goals. For example, my mom didn't make it as far as she would've liked to careerwise, and she never got married, but she did manage to raise me and my sister, so she did "make it" in one of many aspects.

Careerwise it's complicated, it'd be pretty hard for anybody to become an MD if they start at 40, for example, but you can always try. The only factor that will ever limit you in 90% of the things you try is how much money you have and how much you want to succeed in said thing.

>>28174721
the difference between relationships and a lottery is that with a lottery, you are always expected to lose in the long run (your lifetime winnings will statistically be lower than your lifetime spending) but relationships are binary (no matter how many times you lose, once you find someone who suits you, you win).

a normal lottery: pay 1$ for a 10% chance of winning 9$

the dating lottery: pay 1$ for a 10% chance of winning, period.

it's still a gamble (you might run out of money or time or get hurt) but it's a very different type of gamble where your odds of winning goes up over time, instead of staying the same.

Yes, it is absolutely alright. If you try to make moves on a woman and you're not creepy about it the worst thing that will happen almost all of the time is just that she is flattered but is not receptive. I know there's a meme out there that "creepy is just when an unattractive guy does it" but that's not actually true in my experience. In reality, creepy is just when a guy hits on a woman in too awkward a way and/or he is oblivious to her responses and does not take them into account. If you hit on a woman in a fun way, meaning that you are doing it in a way that is fun for you and playful, and you pay attention to her response and do not try to escalate if her response is completely negative, then you won't come off as creepy. Most of the time women's rejections to guys who have basic social skills are not complete rejections of the "go away" type, they are more just of the "I'm kinda flattered but I don't want to pursue this" type. Sometimes women who reject you in that way will change their minds later. Basically, it's not creepy to hit on women if:
1) You are playful and fun about it as opposed to being dreadfully serious "you are my true love blah blah blah" mode
and
2) You pay attention to her response and if it is not positive then you back off a bit and give her some space
Making moves on women in itself is not creepy at all, it is only creepy if you are either dreadfully serious about it, which makes her feel that you might be weird stalker obsessed guy, or if you ignore her responses and try to plow through and monopolize her attention too much when she is sending signals that at the moment she doesn't want that. By the nature of making moves on women, you have to step into her reality a bit and put your cards on the table. As long as you're having fun, not taking things including her reactions too seriously, but also are aware of her reactions and back off a bit if she isn't feeling it, you're not going to come off as creepy to her.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28174639
OP, you have the power to work on your relationships. Family will always be family, you cannot help those ijits, but you can do what you can to mitigate their effects on your life. Be kind to them but have boundaries.

Your relationship too, you don't say why it's not making you happy. Relationships take effort and are not all stars and rainbows. I will point out that relationships are about families and not just avoiding loneliness and boredom. If you and your partner are not committed to each other (and I don't mean legally) then yeah, you should explain your feelings and end it as painless as possible.

If however on the other hand, you're both not making any effort but you think it could work if you actually both do - then write out your feelings and thoughts on a piece of paper and give it to them and explain at the start, and at the end of the letter that you want to improve the relationship but these are your feelings.

I wouldn't change cities in this climate, especially not in tech. I'd be saving furiously because the good days are over again. over 200,000 techs have come onto the market and they're going to be desperate. I'd recommend checking in with your boss and asking him if there's anything extra you could be doing, or if he feels there's something you need to work on so you become more valuable to the company.

If you want to last at a party all night long, it's max 1 standard drink per hour. Sip on water for the rest of the hour.
If you're looking to get buzzed, 2 standard drinks per hour.
Alcohol will be readily absorbed, so don't think you can avoid getting drunk if you consume more than 3 standard drinks per hour.
Lite beers have less alcohol, but you still absorb the carbs which you need to work off over a few days. Enjoy your hangover.
FYI, if you drink water after throwing up, your stomach will want to throw that out again. It's a difficult line to walk - you need the water but too much will see you back at the toilet bowl.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28173994
>not only do i need advice on HOW to move out (deal with landlords, leases, etc.) but how do i face my fears of moving out for the first time?

We can help with both anon. I'm assuming you're in the US btw.

For landlords/leases, etc.:
Leases are normally for 1 year
They will (normally) run a credit check on you which is really to see if you're a deadbeat that won't pay rent. They will also likely ask for pay stubs from your job so they know you can pay rent.
You'll (normally) have to pay a security deposit along with the 1st month's rent. This varies depending on area but they are usually up front about it.
Utilities might or might not be covered in rent (usually not), check before hand.
Landlords need to fix all of problems in your place like leaks, A/C not working, heating, etc.
Let me know if you have other questions

As for your parents/facing fears:
Parents can be real assholes.
Sadly your situation is pretty common (asshole parents)
What you need to do is become your own adult, which is to recognize your parents are just an ordinary man and woman, nothing more or less.

Then work on learning to process your fears over time, and it will take a lot of time.

Find positive people in your life that bring you joy and don't bring you down. Keep making better decisions, always choose joy over sadness in things you do and people you're around.

If you see a chance, take it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28174108
Not that anon, but it's generally recommended that your rent should not exceed 30% of your monthly take home pay. If you've got that covered then it's just a matter finding somewhere suitable for your commute, or just the least shitty option available. You can always check Zillow for rentals in your area just to get a ballpark estimate. Prices can differ significantly from city to city and town to town so you may want to take your time if you don't already have a specific area in mind. As for your budget, you should ideally have one in writing at the start of each month so you know exactly where your money is going. It's also a good idea to put money aside into savings for an emergency fund of at least $1k with a goal for 3-6 months worth of expenses you outlined in your budget.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28174601
We've all felt that one time or another OP, you're definitely not special in that regard.

The great thing about life is it has some awesome times, do you remember one of those times? Go ahead, ask yourself out aloud "what is my most recent happy memory?". Your brain should give you one (maybe not straight away, it might be in a dream).

The other thing about life is that it certain sucks at times. Sounds like you're in one of those periods. I know from my experience, that those times do pass. The good times do come back again.

I have to point out the obvious though - everything is what you make it. If you haven't planned anything or don't have any plans which you're in the middle of - plans which lead you to a better place - such as a less-stressful job - or more money - or a cheaper place to live... then you're going to be unhappy.

Saints are Sinners who keep on trying.

Make a plan (or 2 or 3) to fix the crap in your life. Now break each plan into simpler and simpler steps until you cannot make them any smaller. Now, start doing some of these things. If you cannot... you said 5 years yeah? You've dug your pit for the past 5 years, now you're going to dig yourself out of it for the next 5.
That's only fair, right?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I'm on fin. It has been 8 months. Short term (ignoring hair) side effects were increased libido, increased penis sensitivity, increased ejaculation volume, but decreased thickness, slight ball ache. More medium term I started noticing less enjoyment of alcohol, less desire to get drunk, reduced libido, decreased tolerance to stress, increased anxiety, some muscle aches and fatigue. Now 8 months in I'd say overall the decreased desire and enjoyment of alcohol, the decreased libido, the reduced stress tolerance, muscle aches and fatigue seems here to stay. I am tolerating the side effects because they are tolerable, but I am not ignorant of them. My major concern is over time reduced executive function and drive. I'm concerned that over 5 years I might be generally okay with the status quo were as maybe off fin I'd have started a business, made some moves y'know? If you are wondering why I tolerate any side effects what so ever I believe that everybody will get some side effects on fin, but whether you can tolerate them or not is when they become a problem. I used to jerk off 6 times a day and want sex 2-3 times a day, like I had a problem. Now my libido is a lot more matched to my partners and I'm happy with sex twice a week and I jerk off a couple of times a week. I used to drink way too much, like it was bad for my health and now I drink one or two drinks a week and I rarely get anywhere approaching drunk which is also an improvement in my book. The muscle aches suck, like I get pain in my knee and I feel tired and I feel fucking old, but I've started some daily cardiovascular exercise and I figure that losing a little weight and getting in better condition will help with that and also be a better idea in the long run. Previously I just wanted to power lift and be obese and considered that 'in shape' which is fine, but I couldn't run to save my fucking life and had no endurance.

posts.com: There is a girl at work who was interested in me but I avoided eye contact when she tried to ask me out and generally just avoid her. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28174250
Play the scenario through in your mind first. How do you think she'll react? Positively or negatively?

If you're determined to push ahead with it, you have to do damage control first. Apologise to her and say you just don't date coworkers. Pay close attention to her words. There's a women-word dictionary around somewhere. Suffice to say "ok" and ignoring you means go away.
After a weekend has gone past, you can approach her again and say that you don't date coworkers, but you are available to meet their friends if she has any single friends to set you up with. Make it casual sounding and wander off.

Check with her after a weekend passed and ask her directly if she has any single friends. Again, watch her tone and body language. Take it from there.

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28101153
A job change isn't going to fix your life. You need an entire lifestyle change. I'm 26 and went through something similar around 24. I'm going to recommend something cliche, but it fucking works for reasons I will elaborate on. Get in shape. If you are fat lose weight. If you are skinny hit the gym. Yes it's a physical thing but we are mostly after the mental benefits. When you improve physically it does several things mentally (arguably it has more mental benefits than physical). First is you learn to be disciplined. This obviously effects every aspect of life. You need discipline to escape NEETdom. Next it will give you a taste of that "better life". You will see hard effort turn into tangible rewards that you can be proud of. This can set off a chain reaction into other aspects of life you feel are lacking. Next is confidence. You will be more confident in your self and your abilities and it could be enough of a boost to get you to pounce on opportunities you otherwise would have missed by being passive. Perhaps most important of all it will get you out of the house and give you a hobby that isn't doing anything for you. This can lead to meeting new people and gives you a common interest hobby that you can share and engage with most people over. Don't forget other people will treat you better too.

All of that doesn't even take into account the physical aspects that also play a role in mental health. You would likely see an increase in certain hormones such as testosterone and a decrease in things like estrogen. These hormones play a huge role in mental health and having screwed up hormones probably play a huge role in depression and the like. In my opinion physical improvement is the number one best thing you can do if you are unhappy with your life because it lays the foundation for everything else. This is coming from someone who was fat basically my entire life and was well on my way to being an eternal neet. Getting /fit/ is what saved me.

I understand how you must be feeling, it's completely normal to have a mix of emotions leading up to your wedding day. It's understandable that you may be feeling a bit insecure or embarrassed about the size of your guest list, but I want you to remember that the most important thing about your wedding is the love and union between you and your partner. The number of guests on your side or your partner's side does not define the success or happiness of your wedding.

You should also remind yourself that the people who truly care about you and want to celebrate your special day with you, will be there. The guest list is not a reflection of your worth as a person. You've been reaching out to some people you thought you had good memories with, but if a few of them already declined, it's okay. You don't need to be paranoid. Just focus on the people who are going to be there and make the most of your day.

I consider this like a "withdrawal" symptom. It gets easier with time and you learn how to see things differently and appreciate them more, even at a slower pace.
Reminds me of playing video games in my room as a kid and then my grandpa would come visit and ask me to go play checkers or some shit lol. From something very fast and engaging to something much slower and less eventful. But you can learn to appreciate both in different ways.

posts.com:
>>28171816
Definitely feels like withdrawal. It’s so hard to fight. How long does it usually stick around for?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28171770
Probably depends a lot on the person. For me a week is good to get over the worst of it. Recently I swapped my data plan for a basic talk and text. Not only am I saving a lot of money every month, but I no longer feel the need to even bring my phone with me when I go out unless I'm expecting a call or meeting up with someone.
It's very freeing to not have that on your mind at all. Before it would be like "Shit, I've felt bored for three whole seconds. Time to pull out my phone." A lot of time wasted, especially at the gym between sets or anywhere I'm trying to actually get something done.
Now I have a lot more focus. If I feel bored I just observe my surroundings, people watch, etc. Might even strike up a conversation here and there. Reminds me of when I was a teenager, pre-smart phone era where you had to actually be at home sitting at a computer to use the internet. The rest of the time was all you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28173508
>>28173518
Yeah no it’s not that fucking easy. I’ve been pressure washing (or “pressing” as we call it in the industry) for three years. And take it from me this is not an easy job. For starters you don’t just “become a pressure washer”. You earn it. I spent a year trying to find an apprenticeship with a professional presser. It took dozens of interviews and months of training to beat out hundreds of other candidates and get accepted by one of the major pressers in my city. And then I spent the next two years studying the craft. I didn’t even touch a unit for 6 months. I just learned everything there was to learn. My first pressure washer I had to build out of pvc pipes and compressed air canisters and duct tape and use it to clean a warehouse wall or I would be dropped from the study. I can disassemble and reassemble any pressure washer on the market blindfolded. I can tell you every power setting and water spread you should use on every surface imagineable. And when I finally knew enough to do the job right, THEN and only THEN did I start washing buildings and walls and houses. Now I’m making 60k a year and in a few more years I’ll get my own crew and make double that. So if you’re willing to start at the bottom and work your way to the top with 80 hour work weeks in the outdoors lifting heavy machinery then maybe just MAYBE being a pressure washer is for you

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28171186
I mean decent insurance comes with a decent job, which isn't that expensive depending upon what plans you choose or what your circumstances are. Sure some expenditures take fighting with your insurance, and there's fuck-fuck games they like to play with medical coding on what they consider is "covered" or not, but in the US, as far as I'm aware, medical bills don't effect your credit, and in order to garnish your wages/take other action they have to go through courts, which is costly and usually they'd rather settle for a lesser amount than do that. Common practice here is to ignore medical bills until they start trying to collect, then negotiating with them for a much lower lump sum or a low monthly payment. So I would say so long as you aren't stupid about it, it's mostly okay, just too much bureaucracy.

You have no business calling anyone a retard if you think that human behavior is exactly the same regardless of social circumstances. In a time where social interaction between the sexes was limited, adultery in many cases was legally punishable by death, and a kid out of wedlock was a social death sentence, I can guarantee you that people were a hell of a lot less promiscuous than they are today. Even AFTER the so-called sexual revolution, in the 70s, about 25% of women in the US waited until marriage to have sex (per the CDC's NSFG). Another 40% married their first partner.

Did degenerates exist? Obviously. They always have and always will. Otherwise rules which restricted their behavior wouldn't have been put in place. But to claim that it's not just omnipresent but consistently so throughout history is a load of baseless garbage you should feel bad for posting.

Yeah of course. If he's to the point where he wants to ask me out, I assume we have some chemistry. Fit, nice, plenty of hobbies, confidence to approach me, it's all signs we'd be compatible. So I'd give it a shot if I were single.

Circumstances I'd say yes:
> We have an established friendship
> He has a plan for his career and future, whatever it may be
> He clearly isn't in it for sex
> He asks me *in person*
> We can hold a conversation about topics not relating to sex/relationships
> Asks me out to a very casual date, like coffee or working out together. HIKING DATES ARE BAD!!

What he'd need to say:
> Hey you know I've liked you for a while now, do you ever want to hang out sometime?
> Just so you know, I really like you and I'm down to do XYZ if you're ever up for it
> There's this thing downtown we could go to together, I'm actually pretty into you, we could even call it a date?

I'd likely be to a point where I'm aware he likes me. I really respect a guy that can just come out and say it, then give me a concrete opportunity to reciprocate or say no. Hope that helps

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28173480
Since you work remotely you could work from anywhere
>How feasible is it to live in a place like Thailand for around 500 bucks a month or less?
>rent
Go on fazwaz, or dare I say Craigslist, and see what the prices are. The lowest you could conceivably go on rent is like $150 and that's gonna be outside Farang ghettos and in a non-centralized location. It probably doesn't include utilities either
>muh hostel!
You'd be lucky to find $5 dollars a night
>food
A single Thai dish with rice is like $1.5-3 dollars. Anything western is obviously more expensive. So if you wanted to keep your food budget low you'd have to eat Thai food pretty strictly; either from a hole in the wall restaurant or food cart
>misc
So let's say did that. You're left with $170. That's only about 5000 baht. Lowest monthly rate you could get for a motorbike rental is like 3000 baht = $3 dollars a day. Moto taxis are at least a dollar per trip, even on an app like bolt.
You'd also have to factor in the cost of an ED visa (IMO that's the best visa to stay for ~1 year).

So bottom line you could probably survive "comfortably" imo but that's about it. I don't think you'd find it particularly pleasant though. $1000/mo is a lot more ideaI.
If your expenses are 1000$ a month you can save 2500$ a month
Think about how you can minimize expenses instead of expanding your niche

Naltrexone. Blocks opioid receptors, so it stops you from feeling any of the good things from alcohol. That's why I did it. Nowadays I'm really ill from chronic diseases, with no ability to leave my home.

t. took 2 years community college + 4 years state university to finish my bachelor's because i also started failing when we went to zoom school and nobody has once cared to ask why it took me 6 years or what my GPA was.
